Stave Church
Can only be built in cities following a religion with the Church belief. Construct this building by purchasing it with [ICON_PEACE] Faith. Begins "We Love the King Day" in the City.

Stave churches were wooden, post-and-beam constructions found throughout medieval Scandinavia after the Vikings converted to Christianity. In Sweden alone it is estimated that over 1000 stave churches were built, the oldest dating back to the mid-1100s. Besides their religious function, stave churches often served as meeting halls, cultural centers, courthouses, and even as marketplaces. Early stave churches were palisade constructions, with steeply pitched roofs to shed the heavy snows. The churches had elaborate wooden carvings, usually Christian in design but occasionally depicting pre-Christian heroes and myths. Later, only the corner posts were set in the earth, with planking covering the frame. Currently 30 stave churches remain standing, all save two in Norway.

A Dar-e Mehr, or Fire Temple, is the place of worship for the followers of Zoroastrianism, the ancient religion of Iran (Persia). In the Zoroastrian religion, fire, together with clean water, are agents of ritual purity. Clean, white "ash for the purification ceremonies is regarded as the basis of ritual life", which "are essentially the rites proper to the tending of a domestic fire, for the temple fire is that of the hearth fire raised to a new solemnity". For, one "who sacrifices unto fire with fuel in his hand ..., is given happiness".

It’s 72 metres high, which makes it the tallest in America too. Hardly anything! Experts say it could be a small city due to its considerable size. The Akapana can be built immediately upon founding. You can spend faith to upgrade your Akapana by performing Challa Rituals. Each Challa Ritual gets you closer to reforming your religion, and adds yields to the Akapana, making it a powerful economic boost to your empire.

On the shores of Lake Titicaca are the remains of one of the most powerful and influential cultures to appear in the Andean mountains: Tiwanaku. Long before the Incan Empire, the priests and nobles of Tiwanaku cultivated a hegemony over modern day Bolivia and northern Chile, based solely on cultural and religious influence. Within Tiwanaku was a sprawling complex of temples and courtyards for various rituals and rites, but the greatest of them all was the Akapana, a gargantuan manmade stepped pyramid in the shape of a modified Andean Cross.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The Akapana's resemblance to the nearby mountains was not an accident, just as the mountains surrounding Lake Titicaca feed the great lake with their spring water, the Akapana is believed to have collected rainwater on its flat upper surface and funneled it into a depression at the centre. The centre of the pyramid contained a hole, filled with loose stones, which permitted water to drain out of the Akapana's center, and down into a moat surrounding the temple complex. Thus, the Akapana would have been seen as a holy mountain in its own right, blessing the city with its water. The act of pouring and collecting water and sacred drinks was central to many Andean religions, which presented gifts to the earth by pouring out drinks or burying meals and trinkets.

The Challa rituals are a central part of worship to Pachamama, the earth deity of many Pre-Columbian Andean cultures. Each day, priests would prepare a cup of chicha -- a kind of beer made from corn -- and spill a small amount as an offering to Pachamama before drinking the rest. We do not know for sure where the ritual originated, but the city of Tiwanaku contained one of the oldest and grandest temple complexes where these ceremonies took place.
If you have adopted the Akapana founder belief, use your faith to perform Challa rituals which make your Akapana wonder stronger.

A mausoleum is an external free-standing building constructed as a monument enclosing the interment space or burial chamber of a deceased person or people. A monument without the interment is a cenotaph. A mausoleum may be considered a type of tomb, or the tomb may be considered to be within the mausoleum. A Christian mausoleum sometimes includes a chapel.
